content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a king who had six sons and one daughter.
The children were happy and loved each other dearly, but their mother had died when the youngest was still a baby.
After some years, the king married again, and his new wife was a wicked queen who had no love for the children.
One day, the queen took the six princes into the forest under the pretense of gathering berries.
She led them deep into the woods, where no one could hear their cries, and with a wave of her dark magic, she turned them into six beautiful swans.
The swans flew away, leaving only their little sister behind, who had been too small to join them that day.
The poor girl waited and waited for her brothers to return, but they never did.
Years passed, and she grew into a kind and gentle maiden.
One evening, as she sat by the fire, an old woman appeared before her and said, "Your brothers are not lost—they have been turned into swans by your stepmother’s magic.
If you wish to save them, you must gather stinging nettles from the churchyard, spin them into thread, and weave six shirts.
But beware: you must not speak or laugh for six years, or your brothers will remain swans forever."  The maiden was determined to save her brothers.
That very night, she crept into the churchyard and gathered the nettles, though they stung her hands until they bled.
She spun the thread and wove the shirts, all without speaking a single word.
The people in the kingdom thought her strange, for she never laughed or spoke, but she did not waver in her task.
One day, a young king was hunting in the forest when he came upon the maiden.
He was struck by her beauty and kindness, and though she could not speak, he fell in love with her.
He took her back to his castle and married her, and for a time, they were happy.
But the king’s mother was a cruel woman who did not trust the silent queen.
She whispered lies into her son’s ear, saying that the maiden was a witch who had enchanted him.
The king did not believe her at first, but his mother was cunning.
She stole their newborn child and smeared the queen’s mouth with blood, then accused her of eating the baby.
The king was horrified and ordered his wife to be burned at the stake.
The poor maiden was taken to the pyre, but she did not cry out or beg for mercy.
Instead, she continued weaving the last of the shirts, her fingers moving swiftly even as the flames rose around her.
Just as the fire was about to consume her, the six years came to an end.
Six swans flew down from the sky and landed beside her.
Quickly, she threw the shirts over them, and in an instant, her brothers stood before her—human once more!
The people gasped in wonder, and the king, seeing the truth, rushed to his wife’s side and begged for her forgiveness.
The wicked stepmother and the king’s cruel mother were punished for their deceit, and the maiden and her brothers lived happily ever after.
The king and queen ruled their kingdom with kindness, and the six brothers never left their sister’s side again.
